title: Surgical Apgar Score (SAS) for Postoperative Risk
description: Predicts postoperative risk of major complications and death in patients undergoing major surgery based on intraoperative parameters. This simple 10-point scoring system uses estimated blood loss, lowest heart rate, and lowest mean arterial pressure measured during surgery to provide immediate postoperative risk stratification.

parameters.name: estimated_blood_loss
parameters.description: Total estimated blood loss during the surgical procedure

parameters.name: lowest_mean_arterial_pressure
parameters.description: Lowest mean arterial pressure recorded during the surgical procedure

parameters.name: lowest_heart_rate
parameters.description: Lowest heart rate recorded during the surgical procedure

result.name: score
result.description: Surgical Apgar Score ranging from 0-10 points

ranges.description: Very high risk of major complications
ranges.interpretation: Scores ≤4 indicate very high risk of major postoperative complications and mortality. Consider intensive monitoring, ICU admission, and aggressive perioperative management.
Scores 5-6 indicate high risk of major postoperative complications. Consider enhanced monitoring and close perioperative surveillance.
Scores ≥7 indicate low risk of major postoperative complications. Standard postoperative care and monitoring recommended.

references: Gawande AA, Kwaan MR, Regenbogen SE, Lipsitz SA, Zinner MJ. An Apgar score for surgery. J Am Coll Surg. 2007 Apr;204(2):201-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jamcollsurg.2006.11.011.

Regenbogen SE, Lancaster RT, Lipsitz SR, Greenberg CC, Hutter MM, Gawande AA. Does the Surgical Apgar Score measure intraoperative performance? Ann Surg. 2008 Aug;248(2):320-8. doi: 10.1097/SLA.0b013e318181c6d8.
formula: SAS = EBL points + MAP points + Heart Rate points (total 0-10 points)
notes: Calculate at the end of surgery using intraoperative parameters only
Lower scores correlate with higher risk of major complications and mortality
Useful for determining need for ICU admission and enhanced monitoring
Validated across multiple surgical specialties and procedures
Patients with scores ≤4 had 30-day mortality/morbidity rate of 58.6%
Patients with scores 9-10 had mortality/morbidity rate of only 3.6%
